data.name: BlogsEditor_ApplicationHelpTip
data.value:
This sets the subfolder of the host domain that the blog will appear to be located in.

For example, if you enter “MyBlog” (sans quotes of course) for the application, then the root URL to your blog would be http://[HOSTDOMAIN]/MyBlog/Default.aspx

Leave this value blank if you wish to host your blog in the root of your website.

NOTE: If you specify a sub-folder, you do not need to set up a virtual directory corresponding to the subfolder. But not doing so will require that the blog url include the trailing “Default.aspx” or you will have to configure a Custom 404 page (opens a new window).

In the above example, if you want the URL to be http://[HOSTDOMAIN]/MyBlog/ then you would simply set up a virtual directory (not application) named “MyBlog” pointing to the same location as the webroot.

For more information, please view the configuration docs (opens a new window).

data.name: BlogsEditor_BlogActivated
data.value: Blog Activated and ready to go.

data.name: BlogsEditor_BlogDeactivated
data.value: Blog Inactivated and sent to a retirement community.

data.name: BlogsEditor_FieldRequired
data.value: Emptiness is quite Zen. Still, please enter a value for "{0}".

data.name: BlogsEditor_HelpText
data.value: Use this page to manage the blogs installed on this server. For more information on configuring blogs, see the configuration docs (opens a new window).

data.name: BlogsEditor_HostDomainHelpText
data.value:
Host Domain is the domain name for this blog. If you never plan on setting up another blog on this server, then you do not have to worry about this setting. However, if you decide to add another blog at a later time, it’s important to update this setting for your initial blog.

For example, if you are hosting this blog at http://www.example.com/, the Host Domain would be “www.example.com”.

If you are trying to set this up on your own machine for testing purposes (i.e. it’s not publicly viewable, you might try “localhost” for the host domain.

Important:If you are setting up multiple blogs on the same server, multiple blogs may have the same Host Domain name if they don’t also have the same Subfolder name. However, two blogs with different Host Domains may have the same Subfolder name (though that’s not recommended).

Also, if there are multiple blogs with the same Host Domain Name, they must all have a non-empty Subfolder name defined. For more detailed coverage , please visit the multiple blog configuration docs (opens a new window).
